QPjTk-KYxz86YpXXEZBELA.text: I have previously rated this restaurant highly until last night (Sat 23 Oct, after 8.00pm) when my partner and I went there hoping to have dessert and coffee as we had already eaten somewhere else. We were seated, then when we asked to change for the dessert menus instead the waiter had to go and ask the manager if it was ok, he came back and told us that it was'nt ok. So we just got up and left. We couldn't just have dessert/coffee or dessert wine? Why not? Probably because the manager was on a power trip and too greedy! Shame, we will never go back!au revoir Pierre V...

9EHZNO657oQCiNoucd-zBg.text: I was pleasantly surprised by this place. It's small and wasn't crowded during lunch on a weekday. To sum it up, the food was pretty good and the prices were even better, and everything was better in the company of good friends. We spent an extra half hour in there though we had already signed the bill, and they didn't kick us out!

PNsMviQkC4ia0nuCPhPrhA.text: The surroundings here are lovely. All soft lighting and candles  perfect for a romantic dinner. The set menu is amazing value, I had falafel to start followed by pork chop and red cabbage. The portions are generous and both mine and my friends food were really nice.

B9YBIemi_QWpsTFeW5N96g.text: I went out with a friend for dinner to Pierre. It was a cosy, friendly, relaxed dinning experience. The pianist adds a wonderful touch. Also the wine was great  maybe too good!

6o7RaYQUGVTPLgwEdwv-Tw.text: I have been back to this lovely little French restaurant for my last two birthdays. Both times I have been with groups of six or more and everyone loves it. Last week we went early as we were going to the theatre. They have a very good value for money set menu if you order before 6.30 pm. It is only £8.90 for two courses with supplements for some of the more expensive dishes - with drinks it came to just under £20 per person and the food was lovely. The staff were good though a little quick at asking for more wine - one had just overfilled our glasses in the attempt to empty the bottle and then asked if we wanted another one. Not Yet, please! The wine list is good though and the prices are very reasonable.In the evening a guy comes along to play the piano, which is a really nice touch. The restaurant is quite small and gets really busy because it is so popular. There is a nice buzz but I don't think it would be the best place to go on a first/romantic date. Otherwise I would recommend it to everyone.

TlnWSujYbHzAk2kY6pDIDg.text: Had a good time again in this great little London bistro. Food and service was great. Only point of criticism is that the wine list could have more red French options. But thanks for a great night and the charming live music.

-Xhl3hrkAw0e-UgzPaWBwA.text: Oh la laI come here sometimes with workmates because the set lunch menu of 2 courses for £6 is fantastic. The menu changes often and there is something for everyone. Starter and main or main and pudding. A little French wine and you'll be guaranteed not to get any work done back at the office.

83IgL0pQz-9VfPBP_wBdbg.text: really great little french style bistro we had sunday lunch here with friends the food was excellent and the price very reasonable would def go back def reccermend the moules where to die for

xnCM3Kn2UHgVQuVtAvqXBQ.text: decent french bistro.  good service.  food was good, but nothing to blow you away.

iSCYEnIbDt6OVyZlbGPd2A.text: Pierre Victoire is a cute, pleasant French bistro. The decor is homey and the service is attentive. This weekend was my second visit to the restaurant and I had the steak in red wine bernaise sauce and although there was a bit too much sauce, the steak was tender and delicious. The last time we were here, they also had a pianist playing music which was a welcome addition to our dining experience.

-ZREiVuTf9CzvkbDTu190Q.text: When I found out that there was a lunch special for £10 or less, I thought it was too good to be true. We each got the 2 course meal.  First courses: carrot soup, courgette soup, and something with bacon.  Both the soups had a funny and sour taste that didn't taste right.  The eggplant entree was ok but to my taste, it was very bland, although another person in our party liked it.  I opted for the safest dish - pasta.  I though there was no way they could mess it up.  But they did.  It was a weird mushroom, cheese, nuts pasta that just didn't taste right.  It would have been better if it was just plain pasta.  The husband's fish dish was bad, but he forced himself to eat it.Maybe we ordered the wrong stuff, since everyone seems to think this place is very good.  Whatever it is, It's NOT French. It's also very LOUD, with music blaring. you couldn't hear it.  If you're sitting by the window, don't be surprise to smell the smoke from the smokers outside.  The service is ok by British standards.

nW9WWREYLO3zHfM-oEXriQ.text: A wonderfully quaint restaurant just off busy Oxford Street that dishes out the most delectable (and affordable!) steak frites in Central London. As I said, I recommend their bavette steak w/ red wine, shallots and fries for £10.90. They also boast a fantastic wine and beer selection. Pierre Victoire is definitely THE place to go on a romantic date. Two main courses and a bottle of red will run you about £40--not a bad deal for the quality of both their food and service. Highly recommended!

n8iF-y163CdCZeN7htJASw.text: Pierre Victoire is a fantastic gem in the heart of london's bustling SOHO neighborhood. I've been a regular customer here since I moved to London 3 years ago and my experience is always top notch. Even on the occasions where something has gone slightly awry, the head maitre-de always makes up for it...but more on that later.This is an ideal place for a first or second date, or an intimate party amongst friends and families. The decor is rustic and simple. Mixed candles and a choice bottle of wine on each of the bare wooden tables are offset  by white walls adorned with local artwork (for sale).  And If you're lucky enough to get a table on a saturday night your food will be accompanied by the sweet sounds of their resident piano player. It's all very French.The food is fantastic - i've tried just about everything on the menu and my recommendations are: the duck, which comes with dauphinoise potatoes, bok choi and a delicious asian marinade; the tuna steak; accompanied with legumes and pan fried chorizo, and the steak frites with their signature cream sauce (get it on the side as its very rich). Best of all, all of these aforementioned options are under 15 pounds! When you're dining in the heart of London, this is a very rare thing to come across. If you're hungry enough to attempt either starters, desserts or both, i've got a couple of recommendations here too: for starters - the scallops, steak carpaccio or the mussels - you simply cannot go wrong with any of these! For dessert - the banofee pie wins me over every time.The house wine is very good. They offer 2 house options (lighter/heavier) for both red and white which is a nice touch. The italian house red is my favorite...I know, controversial in a French restaurant! It has a velvety texture with jammy undertones and notes of plum and spice. Best of all, it wont leave you gasping for water or rubbing your temples after the bottle is finished. Alternatively, if you can move up to the pricier options, they've got some fantastic Cabernet Savignon's and merlots on the menu as well. The service can be interesting at times but there is salvation. There are a few clueless looking waitresses on the premises, but the head maitre-de more that makes up for what those gals lack. He's extremely friendly and will always bend over backwards to make sure your visit is the best. I was dining there on a very busy Thursday night. There were 3 of us in my party and we were sitting at a 4 person table. A family of 4 walked in and there were no spare tables big enough to place them at, so Mr Maitre-de came over and very apologetically asked if we wouldn't mind moving to a smaller table. We literally hadn't even had a sip of wine yet so it was totally fine. He felt so bad, however,  that he bought us our bottle of wine and insisted that we each have a glass of amaretto on the house after our meals. Excellent service! I'm all about treating customers well and this more than made up for us having to trek 4 feet away to a slightly smaller table. Thank you sir!! I think i've made my point here...Pierre Victoire is a rare find in London. The city has an abundance of fantastic restaurants but if you want simple, delicious and unpretentious cooking in a cozy environment with a price tag that wont have you sweating steak frites in your sleep, head over to Pierre Victoire.....you'll definitely find me there.

52zm94SUkRmadgPRw8v6Rg.text: My baby chicken was absolutely delicious. The sauce was out of this world, sweet but not too sweet and succulent potatoes.Would definitely recommend.

hPL-L0E-3FfkUNLf7-WCMQ.text: Dining here makes me a little sad. There used to be a whole plethora of Pierre Victiure restaurants throughout the south east, serving good French bistro food at incredible value - around £7 for a 2 course lunchThe chain went bankrupt but somehow this place still survives, keeping the original green waning. It has continued the best traditions of the chain with lunch set menus at £7.90 and dinner set menus at £9.90The menu does look a little more international these days with dishes like Polish pierogi and Armenian lamb bosbash augmenting French classicsThe cooking is rustic, hearty and filling but very correct in the casual way that good French bistros pull off effortlesslyAllez, Pierre Victoire!

etZp9uDiVzkUH4eAsWolrg.text: I love this place.  It's small and rustic.  The service was friendly and fast (and we came on a Saturday evening), and the food (both entree and dessert) was delicious!  If I lived in London, then I'd frequent this place.  Highly recommended!

DFJsXPqQTqpeFTHPIz46bg.text: My partner & I chose this restaurant for the venue for our engagement celebration dinner based on a friend's reccommendation (from a visit years ago) and all the fantastic reviews on Qype. And I'm pleased to say, we were not disappointed! The staff here are amazing. Nothing was too much trouble and they were attentive and helpful to the end. We had a table of 16, taking up most of the basement and I have to say that after seeing the packed ground floor, I actually preferred the intimate basement as it was quieter and better for a large group. The starter of halloumi and beetroot salad was scrumptious a very decent portion (as was the ginormous affogato at the end of our meal - the biggest I've ever seen!). I replaced my frites for mash with my main of steak bavette, was served in a red wine jus with onion and it was delicious (the meat wasn't as melt-in-the-mouth as my friend who opted for the more expensive Steak Frites; my choice next time...). It was a shame that the set menu (2 courses for £9.90) finished at 7pm as that really made it a great option for those on a budget. Top marks for the house red wine - fantastique! I will definitely be coming back. Thanks for a great night!

_4ev8SuJt-aNqbL6ZpeRhw.text: Actually a pleasant surprise.  The food was excellent, and the prices were reasonable.  I ate worse in London for a lot more money.  The piano player was great, and knew several tunes my wife wanted to hear.  Only trouble is the construction right across the street made it a bit crowded.  That, and the drunk the staff had to throw out.  We would definitely recommend this place.

Igsbynmju0e9uEoST1Cj9A.text: I came here for my birthday this year in January with a group of 10 friends, I was a bit late (one has to be fashionably late for their birthday) but the staff were cool about it. On a Saturday night the place is jam packed, the wine is flowing and there is a great buzz about the place. I loved the french music the piano man was playing when i arrived, he played some beautiful tunes from the film Amelie which i love by Yann Tiersen. Oh la la! The food was amazing, I had the tuna steak with chorizo, it's pretty reasonably priced too which was cool and we got a 25% discount as I had a view card (which you can download from view london website) Voila!

1Rd0njU4l5Keqs-KUmn8rA.text: A great regular for me in the Soho area.  The quality of the food is consistently good, and over the years I've tried just about everything. Friendly  and efficient staff who stay with the restaurant, and don't change every other month as you see with many other restaurants.  The (varied and interesting) European/French menu changes over time but retains its classics.  A lively atmosphere, with no attitude or fuss.  Highly recommended.

dRmscwg276cCPmUhWif3Ew.text: Pierre Victoire can be a boat full of mixed emotions.  For me, it usually tilts to the positive side of things.The heavy piano at the entrance, the wooden floors, the dark oak chairs and tables (not if it is oak) and the heavily waxed wine bottles holding a candle are all good starters to a romantic evening.The bread is always fresh, crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside, about the food...Matthew D. is right when he describes the menu as a mess, but I like that.  I don't like however, the supplementary charges for anything that looks really good in the 2 or 3 course menu, I do think that is cheeky but the food is well worth it.About the service...they are a bit careless, but they are french after all.  Maybe because I married one I find that behavior more funny than annoying.

eF24xI-q4OHOCkxF4CBcXA.text: two people - total tab £45 for:(complimentary) basket of french bagguette chunks1 soup of the day (leek & potato with croutons), DELISH!1 seabass (roasted) on top of pan tossed fennel and fried potatoes with (cold) pieces of octapus and calamari sprinkled on top. the fish was to DIE for.. so def a must... not really a good misx with the rest of the seafood 1 rump of lamb with baby potatoes, a grilled tomato on top. Knife DEF optional with this one... which would just fall apart on contact ...1 raspberry white chocolate creme brule - which my friend devoured (i'm just not a big fan myself, so didn't find it all that) and to top it off...1 sticky toffee pudding with vanilla icecream and warm caramel sauce.... D-vine! nuff said!!!two levels... VERY packed, so def not the place to take a date in, unless you're proposing... j/k, you have no place to kneel down.will DEF go back!

5SJ5QNQBhLvkY5KT3nq1AA.text: I have been there yesterday evening to share a dinner, and as I am French, I was waiting for the food's quality served in a French Restaurant in London. I had naturally high expectations!And the result did not disappoint me. It was even a great success! I had oysters on ice with vinaigrette and lemon (usual way of serving) which was really fresh and nice, then a fish just cooked as I like: without heavy and tasty sauce which cut the fish taste. It was served with few potatoes, salad, and just a line of olive oil: definitely french!!! And the +: real Baguette on table and awesome red wine (famous Chateau Neuf du Pape 2005-06). For the price, have a look below on Andrew's review ;) I really wish to come back there, and for French food lovers I strongly advice!

MbsUK2qWi-E-JCY1ivGKIg.text: I went to this restaurant with my folks during a recent trip to London.  Amazing wine, charming ambiance, and great prices by London standards.  This place is not "cheap", but it is a great value.  Every bite of food was velvety and amazing.  Food was flavorful but not overwhelming.  Finally a restaurant that does not over-salt their food. This was our farewell to London and left us wanting more.  My 72 year old father said it is one of the best meals he ever had. Well done.

2K1XhVO3-0soBM4Dngyz0w.text: 10 pound something set menu (2 course before 7pm).... gold...great food... nice feel... service with that beautiful french lack of smilelooking for a romantic-ish feel in soho you can afford... this is the place...oh la la

IoecswUO-mnOAxXXz5riCA.text: I have been to this restaurant six times this year, always happily taking friends and family who are visiting London and it never fails to disappoint. Fantastically priced food which is delicious, lovely ambience, and the paintings on the wall are gorgeous. The lunch and dinner deals are better than value for money!Highly recommend!!

oIUbztOUBOeOBCtjhH07MA.text: This is a fab cheap French restaurant in Soho. The food is top notch for the price; all the usual French fayre. The set dinners are especially good value. I think you have to get there before 7pm to take advantage. There's a lovely atmosphere with dark lighting and candles. What I would say is try and get a table at the top. One night we went and it was full, so they shunted us into a little table downstairs by the kitchen. It was really smelly right by all the grease of the kitchen  definitely not the place for a romantic French meal.

z06Bud_c850JPoUScjP3zw.text: This little French restaurant came highly recommended from our friends. We have dinner here for the first time yesterday. It was a great experience. Although the place look absolutely ordinary; it has a certain character which is out of the ordinary. We went just before 7pm and there was a 'just before 7pm' set menu for £9.90 with quite a good variety extras menu for about £6-7 supplement. I had a seafood and potato spring roll to start and a pan fried sea bass for main course both were amazing for the price we paid! There were four of us , we had 2 bottles of wine and the bill came up to about £150. Great deal given that we have desserts and coffee as well!!! There is a piano next to our table and our friends said that usually there is a pianist playing jazzy tunes so I will try to catch him if I came the next time I go there. I am sure it is going to add to the atmosphere!

TnBOIVC9iZwytDvlJSGPjw.text: I'd been here before although forgotten about it until last night, well, I won't do that again. If you're looking for great value simple French cusine in Soho, you can't go wrong. We all the excellent steak frites, mine was cooked perfectly and was an delicious cut of rib-eye. The wine was decent, the company fun, and they even had a great pianist banging out the standards, including a cake cover! Go there.

hAeNhe8xjypKGjatDqEV6A.text: A Soho institution.They've been serving very tasty and reasonably priced meals here for an age, and it used to be part of a larger chain. This location survived the group going bust, the loyal customers coming back again and again.Just like its sister restaurant Prix Fixe, they offer set-price menus for lunch and up until 7pm, represent ridiculous value for money. The service can be very French at times, but that's to be expected.Unusually, and even more surprising given the price, you can get a very good steak here for just £15. Mine was cooked to perfection.

rNYhWGhtyCOHPsqSaI3qXg.text: As a date venue this was AMAZING, the bohemian atmosphere, miss match cutlery and furniture, helped create a chilled out environment that allowed for me and my date to feel comfortable and at ease!

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom

ZWX4OMgNaISN6z7PmQGEUw.text: This place is very cosy and rustic. I liked the ambiance and the menu was reasonably priced. It's great for catching up with a friend or two over lunch. The food I got, however, reflected the price that we were charged. Mine did anyways. My friend seemed to have enjoyed hers, so maybe it was just bad choices on my end. I don't mind giving it another try if I had to find a place for lunch in the area.

ozcwAmjsx2By7FSh2IQYSw.text: Food is excellent....just a word of advice please shuck your oysters completely before you serve them (I mean make it easy to eat). Main course was excellent and Banoffe pie was great. Decor simple and rustic. Service was a bit rushed. The food came out so quickly and there was little or no gap between courses. Prices are extremely reasonable. Would come back here anytime.

eHFjuRqDjw5xxu50xX78jg.text: A great little find - I'd definitely recommend this place! A solid all round choice, and the atmosphere and food combo makes it quite a good date destination if you're looking for a cute French restaurant. Particularly if you'd find the old dude playing the piano entertainingThe food was good, particularly the 'escargot-style' mussels and the chocolate mousse dessert, and was very reasonably priced for a good restaurant in Soho. Overall the bill was £30 each for 3 courses and wine.The atmosphere in the restaurant was pretty lively generally, but we were downstairs where it was a bit quieter. Overall if you're looking for a cool little place to try out in central London then you should definitely check it out

vLHA9CQ5i-7J819ufYJndw.text: I have a soft spot for this place, it introduced me to good French history food as a teenager.  Good food, nice prices, a restaurant full of character in terms of decor and atmosphere.  Even the set menus which are usually to be avoided in this part of town are good.  A great place to chew the fat and some French food with a bottle of wine with a group of friends or one special friend.  No wonder it's been around so long.

zGVdwzv32i5zWgXFQLyNng.text: A lovely little french bistro in Soho.  Where you can get a decent meal for less than 20 quid. (look at me nonchalantly slipping in a little London slang!)  Nuff sed.  Well...not quite...I had the foie gras to start.  Delish, but a fairly modest portion, so skip it if you are starving. The scallops were the appetiser of choice at the table and went down well.  The rest of our table had the duck for main course, bar one who opted for the pork belly.  I went for the goats cheese salad with the bacon (and other stuff, but my mind goes blank as soon as I mention bacon).  All were lip-smackingly good.  I had a taste of the pork belly and immediately had order-envy.  Blast my attempt at eating out "lite".Filled with a sense of regret at having missed out on the pork, i struck back and ordered the banoffee pie. It didn't quite make up for the missed pork opportunity, but it was pretty decent.Good value, lovely ambiance. Service was "good" by London standards, indifferent by New York standards.  I would recommend this as a relaxed first/second date type of spot.

l57TD6ngGr9jv-PfGVSHNg.text: A cute little restaurant that is for now, unfortunately, hemmed in by a large construction fence at the moment, but its' cute painting-lined walls whisk you away from the street. The somewhat disinterested but efficient service can feel very French, somewhat unlike the menu; it sports all kinds of influences, like haloumi-chorizo skewers, falafel, and hand-made burgers, alongside more French-like zuchini and ricotta crepes and steak frites.The complimentary basket of baguette was warm and crispy and our house red deep and full.  I was very happy with the quality of my meal, and although I wasn't necessarily bowled away by anything stunningly executed, when you factor how little you pay for your 2 course meal, you simply cannot go wrong here.  I left immediately vowing to come back soon.  Be aware that on a friday we had to reserve for our little party, as the secret is out by this point... the construction fence may be the only thing holding back the hordes of savvy eaters.

JGTJKoPVcyXaU4vWU44ZhA.text: Nice place, great food, the wine was decent and it was mid-range in terms of price. Thoroughly enjoyed it, would recommend it to anyone who wants a casual (but nice) bite on a Friday night

uCobhhZ8HL2rTx5csAbwqg.text: Really enjoyed eating here during early July. We ate downstairs in a very cozy room. I loved the candles in the wine bottles - definitely gave it that French feel. Food very good, I had the moules frites, one son had the duck and husband and son had steak - all were very much enjoyed. Service was good.

S4JvOlG8Bk4pd13bXFMbvQ.text: Wow! We went here a Tuesday night - 3 courses for 12 pounds before 7:00 pm, which we thought was a very good price compared to other London restaurants.The ambience here was quite lovely with dripping candles on the tables; and we were even spoiled with live piano playing during our dinner.Now, regarding the food: The menu (it changes from week to week, apparently!) was really exciting in its variety, and we had trouble even choosing. We finally came down with seafood soup, smoked salmon & prawn roulades, thai fish cakes, Beef Bourguignon, and sticky toffee pudding for dessert. Everything was great, lots of different tastes and very good, attentive service throughout. The only thing that can be criticized a bit was the tempo in which the courses was served; we had had all of our courses within 1,5 hour, which felt a tiny bit too fast. But everything else was spot on and we would definitely recommend anyone who is looking for a cozy night out with excellent food for a good price to head for Pierre Victorie!

mot_8xwpbNlpCQDHiRW__g.text: Really nice atmosphere with low lights and candles, and food was delicious - my steak was tender. tasty and cooked just right, and the chocolate mousse was heavenly. Very reasonable prices too...a really good find. Have already recommended to others!

x_EEzZuWNWNhtD-YNW2VMA.text: Effortlessly delightful, purposefully delicious.Pierre Victoire is a diamond in the rough that isn't a hidden a gem in Soho.  Tucked in right next to the local Tesco and on the opposite side of Soho Square, Pierre Victoire packs quite the punch for it's value.I am personally a fan of the Honey Mustard salad with Chicken.  However, their soups are hearty and fulfilling also.  The portions offered will fill you up and you may even have a bit of leftovers depending on what you fancy.Whether you are joining for lunch or for dinner, Pierre Victoire is consistent, reliable and the restaurant itself is one that you know you can go to for a yummy treat day in and day out.

XlFPZ8nZGht4Hz4DEwrw6w.text: Soho on a Friday night with friends doesn't get much better than this delicious eatery. The atmosphere is claustrophobic (you're literally sat on top of each other upstairs), which adds to the French bistro atmosphere they have created. I've been here a few times, but on a recent occasion I realised just how good the food actually was. I had beef with mashed potatoes. The beef was tender and delicious, like it had been stewing in a French kitchen for hours. It's also excellent value.

qq-cun4Q6QIwwacrCj2uuw.text: I often come here with my boyfriend when we want to have a bit of a special meal.  It is romantic enough and not too expensive which does us just fine.  The French cuisine served here is really good and well cared for.  It is best for meat eaters as the steaks are delicious and cooked to perfection.  The inside is quite small, but comfortable.  It is best to eat in the upstairs section since there is often a pianist playing lovely tunes in the evenings, and it feels more breezy.  Booking a table for the upstairs is probably a good idea as this restaurant fills up very quickly.  Last year I also experienced their Christmas meal which was just as delicious, and am hoping to go there again this season.

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom

sE61V6AXHQfpY0BdTwROUg.text: Let's just say I am a fan ... of the price.10 quids before 7pm is extremely reasonable for central London.The food was good. but not unforgettable. Un bon bistro du coin, quoi...

2UQDFpBbvkK_2IEPnz2oMA.text: £7.90+2 Courses from lunch menu+Nice Atmosphere+Good service+Tasty Food=A happy yelperYou've just written yourself into my good books Pierre Victoire; Well done!The dinner menu has an offering of 2 courses for £9.90. On evidence of my lovely falafel starter and loving light chicken fricassee, I will be back to sample more tantalising French flair.

IBBXjXmliIKSTDA4Ng22lg.text: I thought this chain of restaurants was closed but yesterday i was in Dean Street for a business and very surprised to saw it up and running! We popped in for an early dinner. All the ordered food was very nice, tasty, I specially liked my tartar steak. My only criticism is the decor! Could have been better and more French.

DhzvDygKgyYz19RzI1ljHQ.text: I've been to Pierre Victoire a couple of times for their cheap and cheerful early bird menu. Being in central London, just around the corner from Soho Square, it's great for dining at before you head out for the night when eating isn't particularly the main priority. If you order before 7pm from the selected choices two courses are only  £9.90. Bargain! If you pay a £3 or £6 supplement you can incorporate most of the premium dishes from their affordable French menu into your deal, such as the steak that is consistently good, or the sea bass (the quality of their sea food is also another good surprise for such a reasonable price). Their cheap wine list is OK, nothing that your tastebuds will fall in love with, but it doesn't taste like paint stripper either so It will do just fine. Although you don't have one waiter assigned to your table, so you miss out on an intimate service, it does mean a quick turnaround that is convenient for lunch in an hour, and at £7.90 for two courses from the lunch time menu, it wont break the bank either. As my city friend describes it: "A credit-crunch, power lunch." There's always a buzzy atmosphere, constantly topped up with more hungry customers who are conscious of their purse strings. They do add a 12% service charge that seems a little sneaky since as their selling point is a two course meal for under a tenner, but I guess it's only fair. Just be careful that you don't miss this and end up tipping twice.

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom

FNK52uA3SlcsppwjldSnMw.text: We recently dined in Pierre Victoire and it was a mixed experience. Going with my fussy eater mother she was tempted in by the advertised two course menu for Â£9.99 which included steak and frites. We should have reported the owners to trade descriptions because once inside reading the confusing, badly copied, handwritten mess that is the menu we realised that all the steaks and some of the other meat courses all had a supplementary Â£5 charge, which is a bit cheeky. Still, we stayed. The snotty waitress eventually came and took our order, the wine was good and reasonably priced. My lamb was tremendous and my mother enjoyed her steak and frites. She had coffee after and as a culinary treat it was okay. So why the three stars. Mainly the menu, it is a mess, but also the service was appalling. Too much attitude not enough manners. I know a good waiter should never be seen but that only applies to when serving, surely they could be more forthcoming and helpful upon arrival, especially in such a tourist trap area!

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Pierre Victoire

R2p9Mru74Qaa85kx_rxNdQ.text: Teresa C. recommended meeting here one evening.  She told me about the price range and I made an assumption about what I would be getting for my money.Boy!  Did I underestimate this place!  It's quite an understated place.  You could easily walk right by it.  But look out for it if you can. It's got the intimate feel you would expect of a little french bistro.The quality of the food far outweigh the prices.  We got there quite early in the evening on a week night.   We had no reservation but getting a table was easy.  It was starting to pick up as we were leaving.This place is extremely good value for money.

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Fish cakes!

78trBxb8nMv_1NBqS7yBIw.text: I booked online the day before based on reviews I had seen on Yelp. I booked for 9pm and requested a table for two upstairs. I received a immediate booking confirmation via email.My boyfriend and I was running a little late and arrived at 9:20pm. Neither of us had been here before and it had been a while since we've dabbled in French cuisine so we were not sure what to expect... I must say, we were not disappointed!Upon arrival we were immediately shown to our table. The place had a wonderful bubbly atmosphere, with just the right degree of intimacy and class. There were lovely candles on our table and the place was decorated with French art & mirrors.The service was great. Our waitress was very attentive, polite, prompt and a real joy in general, without being overbearing which can be the case in some restaurants! We decided to go for the mussels on the menu for our main dish along side a bottle of white wine. They were delicious and generously proportioned too!It's very rare that I write a review but I think this place deserved it as its great value for money and extremely affordable, quality dining.I would highly recommend it to anyone thinking of going. My partner and I will surely be visiting again!

kby79UBAON4gWSOPBrQ8LA.text: Found this restaurant through YELP. Just tried their Pre-Theatre 3-course set manual. Everything is outstanding with reasonable price. Will definitely be back.

KCtQkbgqG3DwZzpb_VCS1g.text: Amazing value for money. We shared a starter, each had a main plus a bottle of wine. It came to only £60. Shared main was asparagus wrapped in smoked salmon topped with an egg plus beet root. I'm not sure this really worked, to be honest. Egg was fried and the yolk cooked through. Not sure the beet root was needed. Overall, an ok but not very special dish. But the mains were very good. Roasted seabass fillets were served on thick slices of potato and came with one stuffed calamari. The standout of this dish was oddly the pieces of beet root! Delicious. My friend had the lemon sole which was a really good sized piece of fish. Lovely with capers. She said it was a little on the oily side but otherwise very good. Definitely would come back. Very buzzy restaurant with friendly service.

lEBlhqqbTCWwolhSqreBZw.text: There is a pre-theater prix fixe menu, but we were never early enough to take advantage of it.  That said, the price for both meals we enjoyed was fair and, by London standards, inexpensive.  We had beef bourginon and steak frites.  Both were good, and Pierre Victoire would have earned 4 stars based on the food alone.  The fifth star is awarded to the staff.  Extremely friendly and extremely helpful.  I only wish I could remember the name of our Polish waiter so that I could write to the owner.  We came back for a second meal largely based on our experience with our waiter on the first meal.  This is a restaurant that cares about the quality of their food and the dining experience enjoyed by their customers.  Pierre Victoire deserves your business.

S3DbyshQOeFgQH4Vgl2LDA.text: This restaurant is a MUST visit for me whenever I'm visiting London. (10+ years) the quality of food, quality of service has never changed. Food is always delicious, great wine selection, served by fabulous friendly people.If you are near Soho, Oxford Street easy stop.Fixed menu makes it super easy too.I wish we had places like this in The US

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom

3WH5yLw42j4bsB2N3uktOA.text: Went for lunch with a (french) friend and the first impression is of a really nice and cosy tiny restaurant, with wooden tables and large vintage mirrors. The set menu for lunch is really cheap as you can get a whole 2 course meal for around £8 and a 3 course for £11. The quality of the food is impeccable. I mean, I loved it, but my French friend also commended it. If a proper 2 course lunch wouldn't make me too sleepy to go back to work "fully operational" I would likely have lunch here every weekday :)

TLNsHl9ame2JwaNkrobPiw.text: I love this place. I've been here alone, on dates, and in groups. My favourite is always the entrecôte/frites, obviously, I'm French... But the duck confit is also a delight. Start with an appetiser: the mussels or the escargot in a garlic sauce. Finish that with bread. Have some wine. This place offers an intimate setting, candle-lit with quiet jazzy music in the backdrop. You won't be waiting for the meal... You'll be munching on their delicious bread!

DtmwYrnpzV7ZDFiDpC3USw.text: Me and a group of friends had our christmas meal here, all in all there about ten of us.First disappointment was that they had given us someone else's table, so the number of seats was wrong and there were NO CRACKERS! Thankfully, when I asked for them they promptly gave us our required cracker each, otherwise how could it be a Christmas dinner?!The food itself was pretty good, however the setting was more cramped than cosy (we were sitting in a corner downstairs).I don't think I'll try this place again, but perhaps the experience would be different if it was just a meal for two.

T2sHGRtfgXqODr_KA8kwmg.text: I am glad I am not the only one who finds this so called 'gem' of a restaurant to be disappointing. Living in SE and working somewhere near Old Street I don't often frequent Soho for dinner or drinks but I had heard great things about Pierre Victoire. We went here for a friends birthday dinner and I just wasn't impressed. The place is tiny so all night you had people pushing past you and you practically had to climb out of your chair to go to the toilet. We had booked for a fairly big group so I put this down to that. However, we all ordered our mains with a few people ordering starters. The starters came, they were fine, the food was in fact quite tasty. Then came the mains, well all of them except one. Out of a group of 9, most of whom ordered full mains of cooked food, one girl ordered a salad, For some reason this was too difficult for the kitchen and it took nearly an hour (after everyone else had received their food) for her salad (yes salad) to come. The apologies were not particularly heartfelt and when it finally arrived it was sort of thrown in her direction. By this point she was quite upset considering everyone else had finished their food (after waiting as long as we could). We then went to order desserts..and were told that we only had 10 minutes before we had to leave our table as it had been booked by someone else so could we hurry up if we wanted desserts. We couldn't believe it. Putting aside the fact that a 2 hour limit was never communicated to us on booking the table, they had taken over an hour to bring a salad. Needless to say we paid the bill minus the service charge and left the restaurant only to be chased down the street by a waiter demanding we pay the service charge! We explained that we didn't feel the service was good enough and it wasn't until they fetched a manager that we were able to get them to understand. After all that we weren't even offered an apology. Basically it was an awful experience and one I don't want to repeat. Even if it was a one off I doubt i'll ever be going back here again which is a shame as actually the food was delicious!

cbJZ9LfjS5GiojyNHfE7KA.text: Excellent restaurant, as someone living in the USA I was able to get back some great taste from France.The pianists was awesome. We had a great dinner. Thanks a lot!!'

lkVqTMDh-QrhOw6GELRUeQ.text: My friend who is really good at picking restaurants picked this one for our little gathering. The price sounded right. Before 7pm you can get a 2-course meal for under £10 but even if you arent able to make it on time, a main is between £10 - £14.Unfortunately the food more than reflected its price. Every dish we got tasted like it came out of a high school cafeteria. My ribeye and mashed potatoes tasted like they came out of a paper package. The rare seared tuna steak was overcooked, thinly sliced, and tasted like it was on a tangy hot sauce and a bed of hot dogs that were supposed to be chorizo.Dessert was good. The seasonal fruit crumble was well cinnamoned while a taste of the tiramisu, creme brulee and coffee pudding left me satisfied.The best part about the restaurant is that it takes reservations despite being ultra busy. The atmosphere was wonderful too, with candles lit in the bottles and a piano played by someone working for the restaurant.Maybe I'm not ordering the right food, or maybe if I come back before 7pm, i'll feel like the food taste better (when it's cheaper). But I was very disappointed last night.

pZqUaqDRDFW9zJc_nPIiuQ.text: Got in here without a reservation! A French restaurant on Dean Street. Walked in with supreme scepticism. Ok, so worst, we'd break a baguette and butter it up. Let's look at the menu ... oh là là! £12 set menu?!?! I'm sorry, am I not in the overpriced West End? My foie will cost £12 one block over on Frith Street! As the scepticism increased (maybe they were in fact going to serve us buttered up baguette?), our waiter escorted us to a six seater in the middle of the downstairs dining area. Wooden tables teeming on the wooden floor with low lighting mainly from the candles that adorned the tables; almost sticking to each other with very little room to manoeuvre your physical self. Ouch. But very cosy. Just remember, a £12 menu which hasn't been outright slammed in any of the seemingly effortfully written reviews.The baguette did come in, only not buttered, but accompanied with little packets of butter. Mussels, mackerel, onion soup, mushrooms; so a fairly well balanced range of starters. We shared 3 carafes of reasonably priced house wine. I've had superbly cooked steak here, and slow cooked lamb, and both were above average. The menu changes from time to time, so you can always go back for new stuff on the menu. It'll be hard to find serious issues with the food, and for the price, location and the overall experience, I would award this place four stars.The fine print at the bottom of the menu will tell you that you will pay an additional 15% service.

H3XAzb2jBEIYDIUmpEG4Zw.text: Zut Alors! How have I only just discovered this place?Until recently, the only French cuisine I had ever sampled had been baguettes, croissants and pain au chocolats. I'm a regular in the Soho area and thought I had tried all the best restaurants in the area until my recent visit to Pierre Victoire. The interior was stereotypically everything I expected it to be, which I loved. The rustic decor, the wine bottle candles and french memorabilia; all of this along with the low lighting and french music added to the warm and ambient atmosphere. The bistro has great set menus if you are on a budget, but since I was here for a special occasion a little bit of indulgence was required. I started off with the escargot-style grilled mussels in garlic, parsley and Pernod butter with bread crumbs. I wasn't a big fan of mussels until recently and they were delicious. My main course was one of the best I have ever had; confit of duck with dauphinoise potatoes, garlic fine beans and green peppercorn cream. Despite parts of the duck being a bit more chewy that i'd like, overall simply exquisite.To drink, what else would you have in a French restaurant but of course wine! We started with a bottle of Ca'Lunghetta Pinot Grigio Blush and moved on to a bottle of Merlot Rosé. Everyone agreed that the food was delicious and the menus are extensive enough to suit any budget. With a very central and easily accessible location this gem of a restaurant is unfortunately no longer a hidden treasure.I staggered home after one too many glasses of wine after having a very enjoyable evening and will definitely be visiting again.

STGKinXkScg3ejoLCjQMxg.text: I had a dinner with a group of friends on a Saturday night.The food and service was good, well worth their price, we were all satisfied with our food. There was a piano player and a lot of people so the place was very very noisy, which could be a problem if you want to sit down and have a chat. Candles on all table, low light otherwise, it creates a nice cozy atmosphere. The decoration brings back French souvenirs from the 1920's with posters and paintings on the walls.All in all, I'd recommend it.

WZOCa3loWGssJJSSyDGJmQ.text: I loved coming here when I was studying in London. It's located in Soho and is a short walk from the Tottenham Court Road tube stop. It has a low-key atmosphere with beautiful dripping candles and large wooden tables. The servers are always friendly and the dishes are absolutely delicious. They have fantastic gluten free options along with hearty vegetarian entrées. A rarity for French cuisine.

fR7WjevjUZPpoUQKzu0SSg.text: Really unexpectedly excellent!I have to admit, being a little aesthetic snob I was a little horrified at first. Real French style - everything squeezed in the room and not exactly the cleanest or eye pleasing.But since hearing their french "Ello!" I melted.. Such genuinely friendly and accommodating service!! I booked a table for 7 people, 9 people arrived. They promptly prolonged our table, brought more chairs and were so helpful. Their wines we had were super nice and food... OMG! Excellent!!! Traditional and superbly tasty! Seasonal and simple. Menu - about 5 choices in each section (starters, mains, side dishes, desserts) made everything easy.When it came to the bill, it was awesomely small.I totally do recommend and hopefully will come again!

4EDg4RGoRXHVx2n-UKXjRw.text: Very authentic French restaurant. The starters, grilled mussel and steamed mussel, are amazingly delicious. The grilled one is more of a garlic taste and the steamed one is more creamy. Desserts are also beyond my expect, I personally recommend the Crème brûlée.

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Pork
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Mussel

Hy3CeyuygkSBPXEOd5bZgw.text: The food is consistently good and the lunch menu an absolute bargain. I recommend you visit for lunch during the week and avoid dinner on the weekends as the place gets really loud and full of excessively drunk people going out in Soho. Love the staff and great wine list, again, at very reasonable prices.

-UlCblNp7pEAV9GJeLyDdQ.text: Lovely little French bistro, very reasonably priced for Central London. Not fancy, just great Rustic French food. The staff are lovely, they have a piano on the ground floor which gets going in the evenings. Def recommend if you want a really nice French meal in Central London but don't want to break the bank.

hvtXrkY_t5rg29GRcqIRAg.text: Best food and value..honest real food!Staff is fantastic..Come to this restaurant for years and never disappointed..

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom

YmbquIbGEh5YmWHgYrOWAg.text: Landed in London and first meal in the city was at Pierre Victoire on a recommendation from a friend. We went on a Monday at around 530 and were about the 2nd or 3rd table seated for a group of three. Got ourselves a nice window seat so it was great! They had a 2-course or 3-three course set menu for £14.90 or £17.90, respectively. I went with the latter.Had the butternut squash soup, the Conchiglie summer pasta, and creme brulee. I also tried the steamed mussels in white wine and couldn't decide whether I liked that broth more or the soup. Both were amazing with the sliced baguette pieces we received and probably the reasons why I'm giving this 5 stars!

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Creme brulee
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Conchiglie summer pasta, roast peppers, aubergine, baby tomatoes, zucchini, olives, chilli, garlic, and parmesan
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Butternut squash

QQ7egbtkw23EnseVG0CB2A.text: Cosy French restaurant in the heart of Soho. Ideal for a romantic dinner under the low ligths and the parisian atmosphere around. Famous for its mussel pot & the french fries! Reasonable prices and nice service too!

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom

cS8pOEw-kg2ZmqbCt34Cfg.text: Not. Too. Shabby. :)My friends and I were exhausted after a long day of work followed by networking and wanted someplace to eat. We know Yelp isn't a big thing in Europe but still, we love it! I searched a place and saw Pierre Victorie. Not only did it have four stars but also 90 reviews. That's like unheard of in London. Off we went.It was late enough that we didn't need a reservation. Funny enough, we all ordered some version of steak frites. I had heard London typically overlooks meat and I'm a solid medium, slightly medium-rare lover. I asked for it medium and it was perfect. To go with my steak frite was a nice carafe of wine.The service was solid. I just have to remind myself that outside of the US, you have to ask for the check. Which always throws me for a loop. Over all, it's a deserved four stars.

puCXgvdRX9PdvYE6x0Q32g.text: Top restaurant in OxfordWe were in Oxford two nights and we usually go to the two top restaurants for dinners.However, this time we started and finished our trip by going to Pierre Victoire twice!Tina was an excellent server who knew exactly what to recommend as far as food and wine. Don't miss it when in Oxford.

GSPGei9lwfqKi0mEATaUXA.text: Wow what a find! It would never have occurred to me to try this place out if my friend (a life long Londoner) hasn't suggested it for our 'let's celebrate the end of the work week' meal. It was in turn recommended to her by her sixth form French teacher.I hear it used to be a chain but doesn't feel like it. In fact it reminded me so much of a place called 'Bistrot Victoires' in Paris that I had a hard time believing we were still in London and on Dean Street of all places!The menu here is very reasonably priced and the pre-theatre and lunch sets are out of this world value for money. Something to keep in mind next time you're running to Pizza Express before catching a show. My friend and I ordered a la carte though and neither of us regretted our choices. She ordered seabass which was beautifully cooked and I had a bavette steak (so rare to find in the UK) with frites. We shared a side of green beans. Everything was excellent and the food arrived really quickly despite the fact the place was packed to the brim.Dessert was delicious too but not quite as inspired as our mains. I had a simple affogato and my friend ordered a banoffee pie. It would have been nice to see something a little more in keeping with the rest of the menu but no complaints other than that.Mains, desserts, a carafe of wine plus some post-dinner coffee/tea came to about £65 for two of us including service. Will definitely visit again. A great experience. Very happy to that it's now on my radar!

opX38vx_jnuaeov-zZROyQ.text: Stumbled here by accident on a Sunday and I am so glad I did! Lunch entrees are a STEAL for the quality and quantity of French cuisine. £13 for 2 course, £16 for 3 course! I came in with a group of 4 and we all tried different appetizers and entrees, I honestly cannot think of a single bad thing about any plate. The waitstaff and chef were so very thoughtful. When we told them it would be our last meal before our flight back to New York, they were kind enough to seat us by the window, rush our orders and provide us with complimentary Proseccos. A+ all around!

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Lunch entrees!

5ATYS7n9-BCozeiowMkV8Q.text: The scallops and the duck were amazing! I appreciated that the ambiance was intimate, but welcoming of boisterous groups.

yLOhiTRD3tCIowaGk6UGfg.text: My husband and I had a really disappointing experience here last night (thanks TimeOut voucher =/).It started off well: the place was bustling when we got there at 7pm but as we had a rez, we got a table (with the piano to my back) near the entrance straightaway. We got our menus and one of the staff (four were on last night) let me substitute a glass of white wine for the prosecco (as part of the voucher). Warm French baguette bread came out shortly. And then, this is where it mostly goes downhill. I ordered the beetroot cream cheese as a starter and my husband the pork shoulder croquette. For mains, I ordered the Roast Cauliflower and hazelnut carbonara with parmesan and parsley and my husband the Chargrilled Entrecote steak with homemade frites, crispy cos and rocket salad & maitre d butter.And then we waited, and waited, and waited some more.Finally, our apps arrived and the cream cheese platter had a delightful presentation and tasted just as phenomenal. Explosive hints of butter and garlic and honey and OMGGGG so good. My husband said his croquette was middling.Then we waited again. And some more. Then the two tables that sat down AFTER us got their food. And finished their food. And we were STILL WAITING 20 minutes later for our mains.At this point, I nearly walked out.An hour and 20 minutes after we were sat and our orders had been taken and we got our food... and it was tasteless. The pasta looked amazing but was one of the worst I have ever had- completely bland. The meek, scant cauliflower and hazelnuts scatterings couldn't help it at all. Similarly, my husband said his was pretty flavourless as well. I made sure we got the oh-so-stupid gratuity all London restaurants add of 12.5% removed and we left in disgust. The only somewhat saving grace was the waitstaff were all very apologetic, explaining there were only 2 cooks on staff that night. Still, TRULY good customer service (which only happens in the US of course, so silly of me to expect) would have removed the charge for the extra glass of wine I had and/or the 6 pound supplement charge for my husband's steak.I gave my leftover pasta to a homeless person; maybe he would have enjoyed it more!

iZ1zrQMBFrfinTmoV4MOJA.text: Attentive wait staff, good menu selection, fresh food and very tasty. Live pianist played throughout dinner in a candlelit dining room. My friends and I were very pleased all around with our choice to dine here.

HOrlu-TQR1XbabqMh56U1w.text: I went for dinner with an ex-colleague, and it was a great decision. Food was solid. I ordered shredded crab on toast for starter, then the mussels for main. I particular liked my starter -- it was fresh and very flavourful. My main was also good, though I felt like my mussels weren't 100% fresh. Ambience was great -- very cozy and French. Service was prompt as well.Would definitely go back for the great food at very reasonable prices!

6zgwKpoxs9hbNwOC232mzA.text: Got a great Time Out deal and decided to try this place before heading over to Ronnie Scott's. It's a cozy rustic French bistro tucked away on the fringes of lively Soho. We received prompt,  service, actually it seemed a bit rushed but was friendly and attentive.We enjoyed a bubbly prosecco and a starter of steamed mussels in meuniere sauce which were succulent! Our main consisted of piquant, moist cod steamed in parchment infused with a delightful assortment of flavorful spices and herbs, we detected ginger, green onion, red pepper and lemongrass! The raspberry creme brulee and chocolate mousse was decadently delicious!Intimate and romantic, it's a great place to go on date night!

X7PTIjGI6jZLh-S16i6ZIQ.text: Great local spot for steak frites. Ambience is nothing special but food is reasonably priced. appears to be family owned which is also a positive for me as there are only about 20 tables upstairs which makes the place feel more personal. .

bkXYTp21s8Znkjcx_4OogA.text: The Prix-fixe theater menu is an excellent choice if you want great price at a reasonable price.  They have a fine selection of wines and friendly service

Rvx_wjs1duftC1cRgZv3uQ.text: This is a very good value, French-style restaurant, which also caters pretty well for vegetarians.The restaurant itself is rather cosy with an unpretentious, lived-in feel - tables are quite close together, the wooden furniture is second-hand - but not exactly shabby chic. It's very different from the usual Soho joint, and all the better for it. There's a cosy downstairs area as well.As others have said, the set menus - which offer over half a dozen choices of starters and mains - are excellent value for the area. Even the a la carte is not bad, given the quality of the food. Friends who had steaks and the ox cheek were delighted by both quality and quantity - they cook the steaks as you wish - although serving frites in a jar in the modern style doesn't add anything in my view. I had falafel to start and mushroom pappardelle , followed by sticky toffee pudding.Service is efficient and unfussy. One tip - the lighting is very subdued and, while this lends a romantic air, in the evening take a phone with a torch facility!A real find in the area.

sco-WxNZFa_4uuntCaWAJw.text: Great place for a nice pre-theatre dinner.  Conveniently located near the London theatre district, along with an option for a set menu made this a nice choice before a show.  Overall a very nice experience, from the greeting at the door, the prepared table for our reservation, and prompt service.  This is a small restaurant, as very typical of the London restaurants.  We were a party of 4, and all ordered off the pre-theatre menu.  All the dishes were well prepared and delicious, ranging from the steak and fries, duck confit, and entrée salads.  One outstanding appetizer was the grilled mussels which were grilled, removed from the shell, and baked in garlic butter, excellent!  Overall, a wonderful experience and would recommend a visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Front of restaraunt
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Grilled Steak and fries

cUxqEaLLXkRHlfyAX1Z6fg.text: Cozy feeling French bistro style restaurant with good food at a very reasonable price. The suggested house red complimented the beef ribeye very well. My friends had the mussels as a starter and enjoyed them. The candle burning atop an old wine bottle adds a nice touch to the atmosphere. The staff were very friendly and seemed eager to please. A very pleasurable dining experience.Post Script. I was persuaded to have dessert. After agonizing over an amazing array of scrumptious options, I chose the Banoffee Pie. I wasn't disappointed. You won't be either. AND THEN... the pimple faced kid with the impossibly thick accent who was just serving food sits down at the piano an starts "playing around" tickling the ivory while chatting with a waitress. Smooth move kid. Impressively unexpected piano skills.BONUS POINTS!

photos.caption: Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. This kid was serving food just a few minutes ago. Now he's playing the piano beautifully.  Just "playing around".  Nice bonus.
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Banoffee Pie
Photo of Pierre Victoire - London, United Kingdom. Dinner...

xQEBOULYsPiklfed4ofUjQ.text: OK - that's 5-stars for a restaurant in this class. This is up to French standards for a bistro.Having said that PV provide very well cooked food at very good prices for Central London. The ambience is standard French bistro and is no more crowded together than one would expect. The food was well cooked and well presented. The portion size was generous. The bread was fresh - often a good test of a bistro - and again generous.We booked a table for 3 at 8.00pm on a Tuesday. We were seated on time, and while we were there the restaurant was almost full the entire time. Service was courteous and were helpful with one of the party who had dietary needs, and food delivery and clearing were on point: not too quick or slow.Starter and main with one large glass of house red wine each for three and coffee was £95 including 12.5% service charge, and I would eat there again tonight without a qualm. We did not eat dessert.

0NHlHX_tu816HjVYQDiQJw.text: Went there for the first time on Valentine's Day. A 3-course set menu was given on the day, and we ordered baby squid with risotto, mussels cooked in escargot style as appetisers, ribeye steak and duck breast for mains, and sticky toffee pudding and banoffee pie to end the meal. The appetisers were a very nice surprise because the plating was fantastic, let alone the freshness of the squid and creamy yet light risotto. The mussels were tiny but very cutely snuggled in a escargot dish, the flavours were so nice we ordered an extra serving of bread to dip in all the sauces! Ribeye steak was rustic with a hint of chargrilled burntness and it was tender and juicy. Duck breast was a little dry on the edge cuts, but the accompanied relish and dauphinoise potatoes made up for it. Sticky toffee pudding was remarkably lovely with a hot melt-in-mouth toffee centre, but I wish the ice cream was served in a cold container so it wouldn't melt so quickly on the hot plate. Banoffee pie was sadly not what I expected with a thick layer of cream and little chocolate shavings on top, there was not enough caramel with a very thin pie and the bananas were in wholes. The overall texture was more like a banana boat than a banoffee pie.The set dinner was very reasonably priced, speed of service was slow and it was a bit o fa wait on the appetiser (approx. half an hour). The atmosphere however was vibrant and cosy, especially with hearty decorations for Valentine's day. We sat next to the entrance but it was rather packed, so the cold breeze every now and then wasn't too bad (would of course prefer other seating if we had a choice). Will definitely recommend this place to anyone who fancies an intimate French meal!

BjdMPXtVBLWdm8FzKKqTdw.text: Cheap and fast service. Food was average. Had the steamed mussels that was rather bland. The duck confit came in a big portion.
